title: If the universe is not infinite in size, could it still expand forever? If its not infinite in size, does that mean there is a wall or a shell? If the expansion continue forever, will the shell or the wall be destroyed? - Quora

response.answer_text: Hi, I think this is the most difficult concept to wrap your head around, assuming anybody can, even fleetingly, before being overwhelmed in the thought attempt. If you don’t ultimately accept an ostensive definition then that means this is the unanswerable. I think some confuse the universe, which I’m given to understand is not the ‘whole’ thing, with the greater idea of existence. The second is what gives rise to the first, to ‘every’ -thing else. It’s to my mind the ultimate precursor sine qua non. The universe is what we see and ‘see’, what the Hawkings of the world think and talk about and describe in numbers etc: This is not the same thing as ‘all’ of existence. So, Yes, the universe can expand or not or the opposite or something entirely different is going on… and this is as close as we can get. Walls and shells are out, and the question doesn’t ask about destruction of the universe, but again, we cannot get any closer to (some further grasp of) existence than this. Period. Do you see what I mean? And again, don’t conflate universe with existence, or let anybody else pull that one on you either. And while we’re at it, don’t forget the other direction, the tiny, tiny-er, tiny-est, tiny-est-est, uber-tiny-est-est, etc. And the same rules apply going this way, too. So don’t sweat it… and maybe this is a jumping off point for some: it’s just that jumping off doesn’t change anything about the ‘object’ of the effort.

From a purely mathematical point of view the universe is infinite. However the concept or imagining of infinity is something that our finite minds struggle with comprehending. This is compounded with the notion of the “big-bang” as many think of it as an explosion with matter radiating from a central point, a rapidly expanding sphere, which if it was like that would have an edge. When we gaze at the universe we see, as Einstein postulated, Space-time, and time, rather than space, is the important aspect of what we are looking at. Everything in the universe is moving through relative time and is rushing towards infinity or perhaps, and this becomes more philosophical, eternity. Movement (gravity) in all matter is seen to be towards where time slows or stops. Even on our planet, time is relatively faster on a mountain top than at sea-level. The centre of the universe is everywhere because time started everywhere.

If it is finite in size, rather than a wall or shell or other similar ‘edge’, it could wrap back on itself. Often people describe this with a comparison to the curved 2 dimensional surface of a sphere. But that doesn’t necessarily mean that light could circle back on itself given enough time and ignoring any expansion. It could be that far beyond the edge of our observable universe, say in the opposite ‘hemisphere’ from the milky way, there exists a ‘great attractor’ that concentrates the bulk of the mass of the universe in a very large black hole. Light traveling in any direction would be bent such that it would fall into the gravity well of such an object. The edge of our observable universe could be analogous to the event horizon of such an object.

Some things you have to have the ability to forget what you think you know and try to accept those things. These things are still to have an attachment with laws of physics, after all this is where they have come from
